DOC.HEAD: Photos of Mother Teresa and Hitler Found in Noriega's Quarters
EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on pool dispatches.
DOC.TEXT: American troops who stormed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's quarters found photographs of Adolf Hitler and Mother Teresa, a voodoo witches' brewery and a packet of cocaine wrapped in a banana leaf, U.S. officers say. The ousted dictator's homes and offices also contained items ranging from Christmas trees to high-powered arms as well as a collection of pornography, Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of the U.S. Southern Command, and other officers told reporters Friday. A bucket in an upstairs bathroom of one house was filled with a rusty-red looking substance identified as blood. An officer said he did not know what kind of creature the blood came from or what it was used for. Officers said soldiers who burst into the house on the first day of the U.S. intervention here Tuesday narrowly missed capturing four voodoo witches from Brazil. The so-called ``witch house,'' a fortified structure specially built for Noriega, contained such voodoo artifacts as dead fish adorned with yellow ribbons, two bowls of popcorn cluttered with dead flowers, and broken statues. ``This was the brewery for the witches, if you will,'' said Col. Mike Snell, the officer in charge of the area. Thurman said the ``voodoo practitioners ... practiced rituals for Noriega's protection.'' The banana leaf with the cocaine inside it was found in a freezer. Snell said it was part of 50 pounds of the drug found in Noriega's quarters. The general's office in Panama's military barracks at Fort Amador had two display cases containing plastic frogs, electronic toys such as a video wristwatch and framed pictures of Hitler, Mother Teresa and Libyan leader Moammar Ghadafi. His downtown office was adorned with Christmas trees, more electronics and more frogs. Pornography was found at both offices, Snell said. Sgt. 1st Class Joseph Torregrossa said the Fort Amador office also contained expensive prints and ``a lot of expensive weapons, mostly automatic. He had German Lugers, Israeli Uzis, all sorts of real sophisticated stuff.'' Thurman told reporters, ``He was clearly dedicated to outfitting a substantial force, outfitting dignity battalions, which in the long run would have given the U.S. a tremendous challenge in this area.'' U.S. intelligence officials scoured the offices in the hope of finding records that would help trace Noriega's assets. In Washington, Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said financial documents seized by the troops in Noriega's offices might help authorities trace assets and bank holdings stashed in foreign countries. Snell said Noriega had been spotted at the house during the last several months. He said the house was searched for booby traps after pipe bombs were found in it. Lt. Curtis Vinyard said the house had apparently been occupied until shortly before it was stormed by U.S. troops. ``There was still a candle burning,'' he said. The house, on the seacoast near here and close to several U.S. military bases, was stormed by U.S. soldiers on Tuesday, about six hours after the U.S. invasion began.
